hero_desc: Delve into the mysteries of the universe. From the majestic Milky Way to enigmatic black holes and colorful nebulas, discover the secrets the cosmos holds.
galaxia_text1: The Milky Way is our barred spiral galaxy. Its name comes from the luminous band it draws in the night sky, composed of hundreds of billions of stars too distant to be distinguished individually.
galaxia_text2: It has a structure of spiral arms radiating from a dense central bulge where the supermassive black hole Sagittarius A* resides. Our Solar System is located in the Orion Arm, about 26,000 light-years from the galactic core.
planeta_mercurio_desc: The smallest and closest to the Sun. No atmosphere, temperatures range from -180°C to 430°C on the same planet.
planeta_venus_desc: The hottest planet (462°C) covered in sulfuric acid clouds. It rotates in the opposite direction to most planets.
planeta_tierra_desc: Our home. The only known planet with life. 71% of its surface is water and it has a stabilizing natural moon.
planeta_marte_desc: The Red Planet with the highest volcano in the solar system: Olympus Mons (21 km). Main target for future human colonization.
planeta_jupiter_desc: The largest in the solar system. Its Great Red Spot is a storm active for over 400 years. It has 95 known moons.
planeta_saturno_desc: Its ice and rock rings are unique in the solar system. It is so low density it would float in water. It has 146 moons.
planeta_urano_desc: Rotates sideways with an axis tilted 98°. Winds reach 900 km/h and its blue-green color comes from atmospheric methane.
planeta_neptuno_desc: The farthest and windiest: storms of 2,100 km/h. A Neptunian year lasts 165 Earth years. It has 16 known moons.
agujero_desc: At the heart of our galaxy lies a supermassive black hole called Sagittarius A*. With a mass of 4 million suns, it distorts spacetime around it in ways that defy human understanding.
agujero_masa: Colossal mass: 4 million solar masses concentrated in a radius of about 44 million kilometers.
agujero_horizonte: Event horizon: The point of no return. Not even light can escape its gravitational pull.
agujero_tiempo: Time distortion: Near a black hole, time passes slower, as predicted by Einstein's general relativity.
agujero_imagen: First real image: In 2022 the Event Horizon Telescope captured the first image of Sagittarius A* at 26,000 light-years.
agujero_acrecion: Accretion disk: Spinning matter reaches billions of degrees, emitting intense high-energy radiation.
solar_sol_desc: Contains 99.86% of the Solar System's mass. It converts 600 million tons of hydrogen into helium per second through nuclear fusion.
solar_tamano_desc: From the Sun to the heliopause is about 18 billion km. Voyager 1, launched in 1977, took 35 years to cross that boundary.
solar_cinturon_desc: Between Mars and Jupiter there are millions of asteroids. The largest is the dwarf planet Ceres, 940 km in diameter, which also contains water.
solar_oort_desc: A sphere of icy comets surrounding the Solar System up to 100,000 AU from the Sun. It is the reservoir of long-period comets.
solar_enanos_desc: Pluto, Ceres, Eris, Haumea and Makemake are the 5 official dwarf planets. Pluto was reclassified in 2006, sparking scientific debate.
solar_exploracion_desc: NASA, ESA and other agencies have sent probes to all planets. Mars rovers and the James Webb Telescope continue to expand our knowledge.
nebulosas_desc: Nebulas are huge clouds of interstellar gas and dust: the cradle where new stars are born and the legacy of dying ones. Their spectacular colors come from different chemical elements ionized by stellar radiation.
nebulosa_cangrejo_desc: Supernova remnant observed in 1054. Located 6,500 light-years away.
nebulosa_pilares_desc: In the Eagle Nebula. Gas columns where new stars are constantly forming.
nebulosa_orion_desc: The closest visible to the naked eye from Earth, at 1,344 light-years.
nebulosa_eta_desc: One of the most massive and luminous stars, shrouded in its own gas and dust cloud.
nebulosa_hubble_desc: ~10,000 galaxies in one image. Shows the universe 13 billion years ago.
nebulosa_planetaria_desc: The final fate of stars like the Sun: a gas shell ejected when the star dies.
mision_apolo_desc: First mission to land humans on the Moon. Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin walked on the lunar surface.
mision_voyager_desc: Probes that explored the outer planets and now travel in interstellar space, carrying the Golden Record.
mision_hubble_desc: Revolutionized astronomy with incredible deep space images and key discoveries.
mision_webb_desc: The most powerful telescope, observing the universe in infrared to see the first galaxies.
mision_iss_desc: Orbiting laboratory where microgravity experiments are conducted and life in space is studied.
mision_perseverance_desc: NASA rover on Mars, searching for signs of past life and collecting samples for future return.
glosario_agujero_desc: Region of space with gravity so intense that nothing, not even light, can escape.
glosario_supernova_desc: Cataclysmic explosion of a star at the end of its life, can outshine an entire galaxy.
glosario_exoplaneta_desc: Planet orbiting a star other than the Sun. Thousands have been discovered in our galaxy.
glosario_materia_oscura_desc: Invisible form of matter that does not emit radiation, but its presence is inferred by gravitational effects. Makes up 27% of the universe.
glosario_energia_oscura_desc: Mysterious force causing the accelerated expansion of the universe. Represents 68% of the cosmos.
glosario_nebulosa_desc: Cloud of gas and dust in interstellar space, birthplace of stars or remnant of their death.
glosario_pulsar_desc: Rapidly rotating neutron star that emits periodic radiation, like a cosmic lighthouse.
glosario_cuasar_desc: Active nucleus of a distant galaxy, powered by a supermassive black hole, extremely luminous.
constelacion_orion_desc: The Hunter. Its brightest stars are Betelgeuse and Rigel. Visible in winter.
constelacion_osa_mayor_desc: Contains the famous asterism "The Big Dipper". Helps find the North Star.
constelacion_casiopea_desc: Forms a "W" in the sky. Hosts supernova remnants and star clusters.
constelacion_cisne_desc: With the star Deneb. The North America Nebula lies in this region.
curiosidad1: The Universe is 13.8 billion years old
curiosidad1_desc: From the Big Bang to today, the cosmos has evolved forming galaxies, stars, and planetary systems. The Milky Way itself is about 13.6 billion years old.
curiosidad2: More stars than grains of sand
curiosidad2_desc: The observable universe is estimated to contain between 10²³ and 10²⁴ stars, more than all the grains of sand on all Earth's beaches and deserts combined.
curiosidad3_desc: Distant galaxies are moving away from us faster than the speed of light due to the expansion of spacetime itself. This expansion is accelerating due to dark energy.
curiosidad4_desc: Only 5% of the universe is ordinary matter. 27% is dark matter and 68% is dark energy: two great mysteries modern physics does not yet fully understand.
curiosidad5: The Milky Way will collide with Andromeda
curiosidad5_desc: In about 4.5 billion years our galaxy will collide with the Andromeda Galaxy. They will merge into a new elliptical galaxy astronomers call "Milkomeda".
curiosidad6_desc: The carbon, nitrogen, oxygen, and other elements in our bodies were forged inside stars that exploded long before our Sun was born.
curiosidad7_desc: The observable universe contains at least 2 × 10¹² galaxies. Each may harbor hundreds of billions of stars, many with their own planetary systems and perhaps life.
curiosidad8_desc: Radio astronomer Jerry Ehman detected an intense and unexplained radio signal from space. He wrote "Wow!" next to the data. It was never repeated or explained.
timeline_bigbang_desc: The universe begins as a singularity. Space, time, and matter are created.
timeline_estrellas_desc: The first stars (Population III) form and begin producing heavy elements.
timeline_sol_desc: A cloud of gas and dust collapses to form the Sun and the Solar System.
timeline_luna_desc: Apollo 11 lands the first humans on the Moon.
timeline_sgr_desc: The Event Horizon Telescope captures the first image of the black hole at the center of our galaxy.
quiz_pregunta1: What is the supermassive black hole at the center of the Milky Way?
quiz_pregunta2: Approximately how many stars are estimated to be in the Milky Way?
quiz_pregunta3: In what year did humans first set foot on the Moon?
quiz_pregunta4: Which planet has the most famous rings?
quiz_pregunta5: What is the closest galaxy to the Milky Way?
quiz_pregunta6: What type of nebula are the 'Pillars of Creation'?
quiz_pregunta7: What is the approximate temperature of the Sun's core?
footer_texto: Exploring the universe, one star at a time
footer_imagenes: Images: NASA · ESA · Hubble Space Telescope · Wikipedia Commons
